entry.title: Transformation
entry.content: Suppose we are given a univariate Polynomial $f\in \mathbb{Q}[x]$ of degree $n$ with complex roots $\alpha_1, \alpha_2, \ldots, \alpha_n$, and $p\in \mathbb{Q}[x]$ is another Polynomial of degree $m$. We want to study the transformation of the roots of $f$ under the action of $p$. So we want to find the Polynomial whose roots are $p(\alpha_1), p(\alpha_2), \ldots, p(\alpha_n)$. We denote this Polynomial by $T(f,p)$. For the sake of clarity, we use the variable $y$ for $T(f,p)$. By the fundamental theorem of symmetric polynomials it follows that $T(f,p)$ is also a univariate Polynomial in $y$ with coefficients in $\mathbb{Q}$.
entry.summary: Arithmetic circuits for Root transformed polynomials
